item.title: Ordered Deported, Berlin Suspect Slipped Through Germany’s Fingers
item.media:description: A memorial to the victims of Monday’s attack on a Christmas market in Berlin.
item.description: The case of Anis Amri, the suspect in Monday’s attack on a Christmas market, underscores a vexing problem: how to handle masses of virtually stateless wanderers.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE, CARLOTTA GALL and GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Berlin Attack Sets Off Hunt for a Tunisian in Germany
item.media:description: Lukasz Urban, a truck driver from Poland who was found dead in the truck’s cab, is thought to have struggled with the attacker.
item.description: The identity of the Tunisian, Anis Amri, who had been labeled a security threat and was supposed to have been deported months ago, alarmed intelligence officials.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY, JACK EWING, JOANNA BERENDT and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Berlin Attack Poses Toughest Test in Merkel’s 11 Years in Power
item.media:description: The German chancellor, Angela Merkel, and Mayor Michael Müller of Berlin on Tuesday at the site of an attack that left 12 people dead.
item.description: The assault has rendered the chancellor, whose party has already suffered defeats in bellwether votes, more vulnerable as national elections approach in 2017.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: New Ebola Vaccine Gives 100 Percent Protection
item.media:description: Health workers in November 2015 with Mibemba Soumah, infected by Ebola, at a treatment center in Conakry, Guinea.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: After decades of trying, scientists have finally devised a powerful vaccine against a terrifying contagion.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Nearly 300 Are Arrested in Congo as Protests Appear to Wane
item.media:description: Roman Catholic bishops arriving to mediate talks between the opposition and the government of President Joseph Kabila in Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo, on Wednesday. The church has assumed the responsibility of trying to prevent the crisis from spinning out of control.
item.description: Sporadic gunfire rang out over Kinshasa, and witnesses reported clashes in Lubumbashi, but nothing on the scale of the violence on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte of Philippines Calls U.N. Human Rights Chief an ‘Idiot’
item.description: The president also said that Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein was a “son of a bitch” after the diplomat suggested that Mr. Duterte be investigated for murder.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Life in China, Smothered by Smog
item.media:description: Haze over the Forbidden City in Beijing on Tuesday.
item.description: Beijing and other parts of China have for days been under a "red alert" issued because of dangerously bad air quality.
item.dc:creator: ERIN McCANN

item.title: South Korean Court Begins Hearings on Park Geun-hye’s Impeachment
item.media:description: South Korea’s Constitutional Court in Seoul held its first hearing on Thursday to decide whether the impeachment of President Park Geun-Hye was justified. Ms. Park did not attend.
item.description: The Constitutional Court, which will decide whether Ms. Park’s presidency ends, demanded that she account for her whereabouts on the day of a catastrophic ferry sinking in 2014.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Turning Point in Syria as Assad Regains All of Aleppo
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of people have been removed from eastern Aleppo since Dec. 15.
item.description: With tens of thousands of civilians and rebel fighters now evacuated from the city, the Syrian government holds all of Aleppo for the first time since 2012.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Airbus Will Sell 100 Planes to Iran After Similar Boeing Deal
item.media:description: An Airbus A321 featuring the Iranian flag at an Airbus plant in Hamburg, Germany, this week. The acquisition of modern planes is an important achievement for President Hassan Rouhani of Iran.
item.description: The deal was signed despite the risk that a Republican White House and Congress will seek to annul the international nuclear agreement that made it possible.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Despite Blast in Mexico, a Clamor to Rebuild Fireworks Market
item.media:description: An investigator on Wednesday stood amid the wreckage of houses destroyed in an explosion at the San Pablito fireworks market.
item.description: As families congregated in hospitals to visit loved ones or look for the missing, there was scarcely a word of criticism for the failings in accountability that led to the fire.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and AZAM AHMED

item.title: What in the World: On the Trail of Italy’s Manger Hoppers
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Visiting one church after another to see their elaborate Nativity scenes is a popular holiday activity in Italy. Here are some favorites in Rome.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Australia Says It Foiled a Terrorist Plot
item.description: Five men, ages 21 to 26, were to be formally charged for planning to carry out an attack, possibly on Christmas Day, at three different locations in Melbourne.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Jens Risom, Modernist Designer Whose Furniture Still Has Legs, Dies at 100
item.media:description: Jens Risom, a Danish-American furniture designer, at a reception in London in 1961.
item.description: Mr. Risom, a Danish immigrant, fused Scandinavian and rustic American influences in a celebrated armless chair that’s still selling 74 years later, and other modernist pieces for Knoll Studio.
item.dc:creator: JACOB BERNSTEIN

item.title: In Israel, Arrest of Arab Lawmaker Stokes Debate on Loyalty
item.media:description: Basel Ghattas, an Arab member of Israel’s Parliament, in 2015. Mr. Ghattas was accused of smuggling cellphones to Palestinian prisoners.
item.description: Basel Ghattas was arrested on charges of smuggling cellphones to Palestinian prisoners after fellow lawmakers stripped him of his legislative immunity.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Italian Court Sentences American’s Killer to 30-Year Term
item.media:description: Cheik Tidiane Diaw in Florence, Italy, on Thursday. Mr. Diaw was sentenced to 30 years in prison in the death of Ashley Ann Olsen, an American.
item.description: Prosecutors had asked for a life sentence, the strongest possible punishment in Italy, in the murder of Ashley Ann Olsen in her Florence apartment in January.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI and MICHAEL WOLGELENTER

item.title: Anis Amri, Suspect in the Berlin Truck Attack: What We Know
item.media:description: Mustapha Amri, father of Mr. Amri, in Oueslatia, a town in the midwest region of Tunisia.
item.description: A timeline of events in the life of the 24-year-old Tunisian who is wanted for the worst terrorist attack in Germany in decades.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE, GAIA PIANIGIANI and CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Shaken but Undaunted, Berliners Return to Christmas Markets
item.media:description: The Christmas market in Breitscheidplatz in Berlin, where an attack occurred on Monday, reopened on Thursday.
item.description: The market where an attack killed 12 people on Monday reopened on Thursday, a day after the rest of the city’s markets, but the mood in the city was subdued.
item.dc:creator: CHARLY WILDER

item.title: Trilobites: Newly Discovered Prehistoric Bird Lived Near a Balmy North Pole
item.media:description: An artist’s rendering of Tingmiatornis arctica, a newly discovered prehistoric bird that could fly and dive and had teeth.
item.description: The duck-size creature lived in what is now the Canadian Arctic during a time period when a strong greenhouse effect was occurring.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: After 72 Die, Putin Tightens Limits on Consumer Products High in Alcohol
item.media:description: A bottle of the deadly “body lotion” that was confiscated in Irkutsk, Russia.
item.description: The crackdown by the Russian president came after the victims died from drinking a liquid labeled bath lotion and consumed as a cheap substitute for alcohol.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Trump Pressures Obama Over U.N. Resolution on Israeli Settlements
item.media:description: Homes in the Israeli settler outpost of Amona in the West Bank.
item.description: Mr. Trump’s forceful insertion into the matter reflected an unusual public split between incoming and outgoing presidents and underscored the stark shift on Middle East policy ahead.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Ikea Reaches $50 Million Settlement Over Deadly Furniture Accidents
item.media:description: An Ikea store in Brooklyn in 2016.
item.description: The families of three toddler sued the company after their children were crushed to death by Ikea dressers or chests.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: Baltics Journal: Who Tossed On the First Tinsel? Two Baltic Capitals Disagree
item.media:description: A choir at the Christmas tree festival in Riga, Latvia. The city claims that it is the site of the world’s first decorated Christmas tree, in 1510.
item.media:credit: Janis Pipars for The New York Times
item.description: Was it Tallinn in 1441? Or Riga in 1510? More than civic pride is at stake because Christmas-themed travel is lucrative.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL and JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: A Small African Nation Severs Ties with Taiwan, and Beijing Applauds
item.media:description: The flags of countries that have diplomatic relations with Taiwan flying in Taipei on Wednesday. With São Tomé and Príncipe’s decision to sever ties with the island, those countries now number 21.
item.description: The decision by São Tomé and Príncipe reduces the number of countries that have formal relations with Taipei to 21.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Israeli, Italian and Polish Citizens Were Among Victims of Berlin Attack
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial on Wednesday near the site of the terrorist assault in Berlin.
item.description: The terrorist assault on a Christmas market in the German capital killed 12 people, most of whom have not been identified, and wounded 48 others.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER, JOANNA BERENDT and GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: U.S. Returns Some Okinawa Land to Japan, but Unease Endures
item.media:description: Protesters gathered in Nago on Thursday, not far from a ceremony transferring nearly 10,000 acres of land on Okinawa Island to Japanese control.
item.description: Like many encounters between the American military and residents of the island, the transfer of nearly 10,000 acres has stirred controversy.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Propaganda Video Warns of West’s ‘Devilish Claws’
item.media:description: Joshua Wong, a student leader, delivering a speech in 2014 during protests in Hong Kong calling for greater democracy. A video spreading widely online in China depicts the city as a base for Western subversion, whipped up by figures like Mr. Wong.
item.description: A video shows how threats to party control that can seem unrelated to outsiders are often seen inside the party as calculated moves in a plot to bring it down.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: U.N. Inquiry Alludes to Russia and Syria as Bombers of Aid Convoy
item.media:description: The scene on Sept. 20, the morning after a deadly attack on a convoy delivering aid on the outskirts of Aleppo, Syria.
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A panel created to investigate the deadly Sept. 19 assault on a humanitarian aid convoy in northern Syria said bombs from aircraft were responsible.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Trump Taps Peter Navarro, Vocal Critic of China, for New Trade Post
item.media:description: Peter Navarro, center, with Mark Cuban, left. Mr. Navarro was picked on Wednesday to lead a new White House office overseeing American trade and industrial policy.
item.description: The president-elect also said that the billionaire investor Carl Icahn would serve as a special adviser on regulatory issues.
item.dc:creator: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM

item.title: Dispatches: On Patrol With Police as Philippines Battles Drugs
item.media:description: In Manila last month, the Santa Ana station jail — a single cell, about 12 feet wide by 20 feet deep — held 48 men and had a single toilet.
item.description: A reporter heads out with officers to see, from their perspective, the nation’s deadly crackdown on drug users and dealers.
item.dc:creator: AURORA ALMENDRAL

item.title: Spiking Temperatures in the Arctic Startle Scientists
item.media:description: The cruise ship Crystal Serenity, anchored outside Nome, Alaska, in August, before its inaugural voyage through the Northwest Passage. The trip would not have been possible before climate change led to diminished sea ice coverage.
item.description: A spate of extreme warmth is linked to climate change, and may lead to shrinking ice coverage and even more warming in the region, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN and JOHN SCHWARTZ

item.title: Hezbollah Is Using U.S.-Made Military Vehicles in Syria, Israel Says
item.description: If American-made armored personnel carriers passed to Hezbollah from the Lebanese Army, as an Israeli official said, that might point to a broader leakage of weapons.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and BEN HUBBARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Romania Set for First Female, and First Muslim, Prime Minister
item.media:description: Sevil Shhaideh is a relatively little-known figure who served as minister of regional development for six months in Romania’s last Social Democrat-led government.
item.description: Sevil Shhaideh, a relatively little-known figure in Romanian politics, was nominated by the majority Social Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Hyundai’s U.S. Chief Is Out, as Automaker Seeks to Rekindle Growth
item.description: David Zuchowski had led the American unit of the South Korean company for nearly three years, as the U.S. market shifted away from Hyundai’s strengths.
item.dc:creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

item.title: Taliban Attack Lawmaker’s Kabul Home
item.media:description: Security forces on Wednesday patrolling the site of an attack on the home of Mir Wali, a lawmaker, in Kabul, Afghanistan.
item.description: Officials said gunmen killed at least seven people at the home of Mir Wali, a prominent figure in the southern province of Helmand, who survived.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Erdogan Says Follower of Gulen, His Rival, Killed Russian Envoy
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Istanbul this week. The Russian government has been far more cautious in public statements about the killer’s possible affiliation or motive.
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan doubled down on accusations that the assassin’s fealty lay with Fethullah Gulen, an outlawed Muslim cleric.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Spanish Banks Ordered to Repay Customers Over Unfair Mortgages
item.media:description: BBVA, one of Spain’s largest banks, said it expected a European Court of Justice ruling on Wednesday to reduce its profit by about 404 million euros.
item.description: The ruling centered on the use of a clause in mortgage contracts that meant banks did not have to pass on the full savings from falling interest rates.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: YouTube Stars Say They Were Removed From Delta Flight for Speaking Arabic
item.media:description: Adam Saleh, center, and Slim Albaher, right, after arriving at Kennedy International Airport on Wednesday. The men said they had been asked to leave their flight at Heathrow Airport after Mr. Saleh spoke in Arabic to his mother by phone.
item.media:credit: Kevin Hagen for The New York Times
item.description: Delta stood by its actions, saying the two customers, Adam Saleh and Slim Albaher, had “sought to disrupt the cabin with provocative behavior, including shouting.”
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: Erdogan Embraces Bana al-Abed, Who Brought Child’s View of Aleppo to Twitter
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey hugged Bana al-Abed, a 7-year-old girl from Aleppo.
item.description: Bana became a global sensation over the past few months for messages and videos posted to her Twitter account describing the horrors of Syria’s war in intimate detail.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Sinosphere: Smog Grips China, but Exam Goes on Outdoors
item.description: Pupils wore flimsy masks that afforded little protection and quickly came to symbolize the frustration that people feel about the pollution.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Donald Trump, Seeking Ambassadors, Sorts Through Competing Priorities
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump was greeted by Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, his nominee for ambassador to China, at a “thank you” rally in Des Moines this month.
item.description: Intense jockeying for diplomatic posts has begun among donors and loyalists to Mr. Trump and, in some cases, among people close to his children.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: Germany Seeks Tunisian Tied to Berlin Christmas Market Attack
item.media:description: Anis Amri is wanted by German police in connection with the Berlin Christmas market attack.
item.description: The man was denied asylum in Germany and was considered a security risk. He is wanted in connection with a truck attack that killed 12 people and hurt 48.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Nigel Farage Called a ‘Disgrace’ for Remarks About Berlin Attack
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, former leader of the U.K. Independence Party, in London in November.
item.description: The former UKIP leader blamed the terrorist assault on Angela Merkel’s refugee policy, then impugned the husband of a British lawmaker murdered by a right-wing extremist.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: James Taylor Cancels Concert in Philippines, Citing Bloody Antidrug Campaign
item.media:description: A billboard on Wednesday promoting the James Taylor concert in Manila. Mr. Taylor said the decision would not affect plans for the rest of his tour.
item.description: The musician said reports of “summary executions of suspected offenders without trial or judicial process” in the Philippines were “deeply concerning.”
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Sinosphere: ‘Great Wall’ Producer on What Hollywood and China Can Teach Each Other
item.media:description: Matt Damon plays a mercenary in “The Great Wall,” Zhang Yimou’s epic thriller in which monsters face off against humanity at the Great Wall of China.
item.description: Peter Loehr, chief of Legendary East, discusses the making of the $150 million co-production, the biggest so far, and criticism over the casting of its star, Matt Damon.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Only a Rumbling Volcano Could Make North Korea and the West Play Nice
item.media:description: Mount Paektu, on the border between North Korea and China, erupted 1,000 years ago in one of the most violent volcanic explosions in human history.
item.description: Mount Paektu is sacred to the North Korean people. When a swarm of tiny earthquakes were recorded, the reclusive country decided it needed help.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Egypt’s Cruelty to Christians
item.media:description: A picture of a cathedral complex bomb attack victim during her funeral procession in Cairo this month.
item.description: Islamist terrorists just bombed a church in a horrific attack, but all too often Copts are the victims of ordinary mob violence.
item.dc:creator: MONA ELTAHAWY

item.title: Editorial: Poland’s Tragic Turn
item.media:description: Protesters holding copies of Poland’s constitution shout slogans during an anti-government demonstration, in Warsaw.
item.description: A dire warning should frighten all democratic nations in which populist rulers have taken or threaten to take power.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Rex Tillerson’s Special Friend in the Kremlin
item.media:description: Igor Sechin, left, and Rex Tillerson at the 21st World Petroleum Congress in Moscow.
item.description: Trump’s secretary of state nominee is a gift for Putin. He’s an even bigger gift for Putin’s right-hand man.
item.dc:creator: OLEG KASHIN

item.title: Italy Overwhelmed
item.description: Italy is overwhelmed by the influx of migrants. But three citizens are making a difference in migrants’ lives, and even in their deaths.
item.dc:creator: DAN RUETENIK
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
